description: Comprehensive Algebra concepts with definitions, formulas, proofs, and examples

definition.text: A linear equation is an algebraic equation in which each term is either a constant or the product of a constant and a single variable raised to the first power. The graph of a linear equation is always a straight line.

keyFormulas.name: Standard Form
keyFormulas.meaning: Where 'a' is the coefficient (a ≠ 0), 'x' is the variable, and 'b' is the constant term

keyFormulas.name: Solution Formula
keyFormulas.meaning: The value of x that satisfies the equation

keyFormulas.name: Slope-Intercept Form
keyFormulas.meaning: Where 'm' is the slope and 'b' is the y-intercept

keyFormulas.name: Point-Slope Form
keyFormulas.meaning: Equation through point (x₁, y₁) with slope m

steps.explanation: Move the constant to the right side
Isolate x by dividing by its coefficient
Collect variable terms on one side

examples.question: Find the equation of a line with slope 3 passing through (2, 5)

steps.action: Use point-slope form: y - y₁ = m(x - x₁)

steps.explanation: Add 5 to both sides for slope-intercept form

realWorldApplications.title: Cost Calculation
realWorldApplications.description: If a taxi charges $3 base fare plus $2 per mile, the total cost C for m miles is C = 2m + 3

proofOfConcept.theorem: Every linear equation ax + b = 0 (where a ≠ 0) has exactly one solution
proof: Subtract b from both sides: ax = -b
Since a ≠ 0, we can divide both sides by a: x = -b/a
This is a unique value, proving there is exactly one solution

definition.text: A quadratic equation is a second-degree polynomial equation in a single variable x, with the general form ax² + bx + c = 0, where a ≠ 0. The graph of a quadratic function is a parabola.

keyFormulas.name: Standard Form
keyFormulas.meaning: Where a ≠ 0, a is the leading coefficient

keyFormulas.name: Quadratic Formula
keyFormulas.meaning: Universal formula to find roots of any quadratic equation

keyFormulas.name: Discriminant
keyFormulas.meaning: Determines the nature of roots: D > 0 (two real), D = 0 (one real), D < 0 (complex)

keyFormulas.name: Vertex Form
keyFormulas.meaning: Where (h, k) is the vertex of the parabola

keyFormulas.name: Sum and Product of Roots
keyFormulas.meaning: Vieta's formulas relating roots to coefficients

steps.action: Find two numbers that multiply to 6 and add to -5

steps.explanation: If ab = 0, then a = 0 or b = 0
From standard form ax² + bx + c = 0
D > 0 means two distinct real roots

examples.question: Find the vertex and axis of symmetry of y = x² - 4x + 7

steps.explanation: Using vertex formula with a = 1, b = -4
Substitute x = 2 into the original equation

examples.verification: The parabola opens upward (a = 1 > 0) with minimum at (2, 3)

realWorldApplications.title: Projectile Motion
realWorldApplications.description: Height of a ball: h(t) = -16t² + v₀t + h₀, where v₀ is initial velocity

realWorldApplications.title: Area Optimization
realWorldApplications.description: Finding maximum area of a rectangle with fixed perimeter

proof: Complete the square by adding (b/2a)² to both sides:

definition.text: A polynomial is an expression consisting of variables and coefficients, involving only addition, subtraction, multiplication, and non-negative integer exponents. The degree of a polynomial is the highest power of the variable.

keyFormulas.name: General Form
keyFormulas.meaning: Where aₙ ≠ 0 and n is the degree

keyFormulas.name: Factored Form
keyFormulas.meaning: Where r₁, r₂, ..., rₙ are the roots

keyFormulas.name: Factor Theorem
keyFormulas.meaning: If a is a root, (x - a) divides P(x) evenly

steps.explanation: Combine terms with same power of x

examples.question: Find if (x - 2) is a factor of P(x) = x³ - 3x² - 4x + 12

steps.action: Apply Factor Theorem: Check if P(2) = 0

examples.finalAnswer: Yes, (x - 2) is a factor of P(x)

realWorldApplications.title: Curve Fitting
realWorldApplications.description: Polynomials are used to model data points in statistics and engineering

realWorldApplications.title: Computer Graphics
realWorldApplications.description: Bézier curves use polynomials to create smooth curves

definition.text: A function is a relation that assigns exactly one output value to each input value. If f is a function from set A to set B, written f: A → B, then for each element x in A, there exists exactly one element y in B such that f(x) = y.

keyFormulas.name: Function Notation
keyFormulas.meaning: y is the output when x is the input

keyFormulas.name: Function Composition
keyFormulas.meaning: Apply g first, then apply f to the result

keyFormulas.name: Vertical Line Test
keyFormulas.formula: Each vertical line crosses graph at most once
keyFormulas.latex: \text{Each vertical line crosses graph at most once}
keyFormulas.meaning: A graph represents a function if and only if it passes this test

examples.question: If f(x) = x² and g(x) = x + 1, find (f ∘ g)(3)

steps.explanation: Standard first step for finding inverse

realWorldApplications.title: Economics
realWorldApplications.description: Demand functions relate price to quantity demanded

realWorldApplications.title: Physics
realWorldApplications.description: Position as a function of time: s(t)

definition.text: A logarithm is the inverse operation of exponentiation. The logarithm of a number x to base b, written log_b(x), is the exponent to which b must be raised to produce x. If b^y = x, then log_b(x) = y.

keyFormulas.name: Definition
keyFormulas.meaning: Logarithm is the inverse of exponentiation

keyFormulas.name: Product Rule
keyFormulas.meaning: Log of a product is sum of logs

keyFormulas.name: Quotient Rule
keyFormulas.meaning: Log of a quotient is difference of logs

examples.question: Simplify: log₁₀(1000) + log₁₀(10)

steps.explanation: 10 to what power gives each number

examples.verification: Or using product rule: log₁₀(1000 × 10) = log₁₀(10000) = 4 ✓

definition.text: A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers, symbols, or expressions arranged in rows and columns. Matrices are fundamental tools in linear algebra, used to represent linear transformations and solve systems of linear equations.

keyFormulas.name: Scalar Multiplication
keyFormulas.meaning: Multiply each element by scalar k

keyFormulas.name: 2×2 Determinant
keyFormulas.formula: det([a b; c d]) = ad - bc
keyFormulas.latex: \det\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = ad - bc

keyFormulas.name: Identity Matrix
keyFormulas.meaning: AI = IA = A for any matrix A

examples.question: Add: [1 2; 3 4] + [5 6; 7 8]
examples.verification: Both matrices are 2×2, addition is valid

examples.question: Find the determinant of [3 2; 1 4]
examples.verification: Since det ≠ 0, this matrix is invertible

realWorldApplications.title: Machine Learning
realWorldApplications.description: Neural networks use matrix multiplication extensively

definition.text: An inequality is a mathematical statement that compares two expressions using symbols like < (less than), > (greater than), ≤ (less than or equal), or ≥ (greater than or equal). Unlike equations, inequalities typically have infinitely many solutions, forming intervals on the number line.

keyFormulas.name: Addition Property
keyFormulas.formula: If a < b, then a + c < b + c
keyFormulas.latex: a < b \Rightarrow a + c < b + c

keyFormulas.name: Multiplication (Positive)
keyFormulas.formula: If a < b and c > 0, then ac < bc

keyFormulas.name: Multiplication (Negative)
keyFormulas.formula: If a < b and c < 0, then ac > bc

definition.text: A system of equations is a set of two or more equations with the same variables. The solution is the set of values that satisfy ALL equations simultaneously. Systems can have one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solution.

keyFormulas.name: Substitution Method
keyFormulas.formula: Solve one equation for a variable, substitute into other

keyFormulas.name: Elimination Method
keyFormulas.formula: Add/subtract equations to eliminate a variable

definition.text: A sequence is an ordered list of numbers following a pattern, denoted aₙ. A series is the sum of terms in a sequence. Arithmetic sequences have a constant difference, geometric sequences have a constant ratio.

keyFormulas.name: Arithmetic Sequence nth Term
keyFormulas.meaning: First term plus (n-1) times common difference

keyFormulas.name: Geometric Sequence nth Term
keyFormulas.meaning: First term times ratio to the (n-1) power

definition.text: Factoring is the process of breaking down a polynomial into a product of simpler expressions. It's the reverse of expanding (distributing). Key patterns include common factors, difference of squares, perfect square trinomials, and grouping.

keyFormulas.name: Trinomial (x² + bx + c)
keyFormulas.formula: x² + bx + c = (x + p)(x + q) where p + q = b and pq = c
keyFormulas.meaning: Find factors that add to b and multiply to c

steps.explanation: a² - b² pattern with a=x, b=3

steps.action: Find two numbers that add to 5 and multiply to 6

steps.result: Find factors of 6 that add to 7

steps.explanation: Group first two and last two terms

realWorldApplications.title: Solving Equations
realWorldApplications.description: Zero product property requires factored form

definition.text: The absolute value of a number is its distance from zero on the number line, always non-negative. |x| equals x if x ≥ 0, and -x if x < 0. Absolute value equations and inequalities require considering two cases.

steps.explanation: |a| = b means a = b or a = -b
|a| > b means a < -b OR a > b

definition.text: Radical expressions contain roots (square roots, cube roots, etc.). Simplifying radicals involves finding perfect square factors. Radicals can be added, subtracted, multiplied, and divided following specific rules.

keyFormulas.name: Product Rule for Radicals
keyFormulas.meaning: Split or combine under the radical

definition.text: Exponential functions have the form f(x) = aˣ where a > 0 and a ≠ 1. They model growth (a > 1) or decay (0 < a < 1). The most important base is e ≈ 2.718, the natural exponential.

keyFormulas.name: Exponential Decay
keyFormulas.formula: A = A₀(1 - r)ᵗ or A = A₀e^(-kt)

examples.question: $1000 invested at 5% annual interest, compounded monthly. What is it worth after 3 years?
examples.verification: Simple interest would be $1150, compound is more ✓

examples.question: Carbon-14 has half-life of 5730 years. If a fossil has 25% of original C-14, how old is it?
examples.finalAnswer: The fossil is about 11,460 years old

definition.text: Linear functions graph as straight lines. The slope-intercept form y = mx + b directly shows the slope (m) and y-intercept (b). Understanding slopes and intercepts is fundamental to algebra and calculus.

keyFormulas.name: Point-Slope Form
keyFormulas.meaning: Through point (x₁, y₁) with slope m

keyFormulas.name: Standard Form
keyFormulas.meaning: A, B, C are integers, A ≥ 0

keyFormulas.name: Parallel Lines
keyFormulas.formula: Parallel lines have equal slopes: m₁ = m₂

examples.question: Find the slope of the line through (2, 5) and (6, 13)
examples.verification: Line rises 2 units for every 1 unit right

examples.question: Write the equation of line with slope 3 through point (2, -1)
Find equation of line perpendicular to y = 2x + 3 through (4, 1)

realWorldApplications.title: Cost Functions
realWorldApplications.description: Fixed cost + variable cost per unit

realWorldApplications.title: Depreciation
realWorldApplications.description: Linear decline in value over time

definition.text: Word problems require translating English into mathematical equations. Key skills include identifying unknowns, setting up equations, solving, and checking answers in context. Common types include age, mixture, distance-rate-time, and work problems.

examples.question: John is 5 years older than Mary. In 3 years, John will be twice Mary's current age. How old is Mary now?

steps.explanation: In 3 years, John = 2 × Mary's current age

examples.question: A train leaves at 60 mph. An hour later, a faster train leaves at 80 mph. When does the faster train catch up?

steps.result: Let t = time faster train travels

examples.finalAnswer: Faster train catches up in 3 hours (both travel 240 miles)

definition.text: Completing the square transforms a quadratic expression into a perfect square trinomial plus a constant. It's used to solve quadratics, derive the quadratic formula, and convert to vertex form.

keyFormulas.name: Perfect Square Pattern
keyFormulas.meaning: Add square of half the linear coefficient

keyFormulas.name: Vertex Form
keyFormulas.meaning: Vertex at (h, k), opens up if a > 0

keyFormulas.name: Steps to Complete
keyFormulas.formula: 1) Move constant 2) Half of b 3) Square it 4) Add to both sides

examples.question: Solve x² + 6x - 7 = 0 by completing the square

steps.action: Factor left side as perfect square
Take square root of both sides

examples.question: Write y = x² - 4x + 7 in vertex form

definition.text: A rational expression is a fraction where numerator and denominator are polynomials. Operations include simplifying, adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing. Domain excludes values making the denominator zero.

steps.explanation: Find factors of -6 that add to -1

examples.question: Add: 2/x + 3/(x+1)
examples.verification: Can expand denominator or leave factored

definition.text: Complex numbers extend real numbers by including i = √(-1). They allow solutions to all polynomial equations. Operations follow standard algebra rules with i² = -1.

keyFormulas.name: Powers of i
keyFormulas.formula: i¹ = i, i² = -1, i³ = -i, i⁴ = 1, then repeats

keyFormulas.name: Complex Conjugate
keyFormulas.formula: If z = a + bi, then z̄ = a - bi

keyFormulas.name: Modulus (Absolute Value)
keyFormulas.meaning: Distance from origin in complex plane

examples.question: Divide: (5 + 3i)/(2 - i)
examples.verification: Can verify by multiplying answer by (2-i)

steps.explanation: Same as i^1 since remainder is 1

definition.text: Direct variation: y increases as x increases (y = kx). Inverse variation: y decreases as x increases (y = k/x). The constant k is called the constant of variation or proportionality.

keyFormulas.name: Direct Variation
keyFormulas.meaning: y is directly proportional to x

keyFormulas.name: Inverse Variation
keyFormulas.meaning: y is inversely proportional to x

keyFormulas.name: Joint Variation
keyFormulas.meaning: z varies directly with both x and y

examples.question: y varies directly with x. If y = 12 when x = 4, find y when x = 7

steps.action: Use k to find new y

examples.question: y varies inversely with x. If y = 8 when x = 3, find y when x = 6

steps.action: Use k to find new y
